awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Plastic Ceramics: The Role of Grain Boundaries During Laser Shock Peening
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Laser shock peening (LSP) is a new surface engineering method that has been proven to prevent crack growth in several ceramic materials, which are inherently brittle. In particular, success has been found with ceramics suitable for applications in extreme environments (e.g., hypersonic vehicles, gas-turbine engines, and armor). The general applicability of this technique is impeded because the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. The goal of this project is to identify the role internal interfaces play during LSP to guide future material design, which will extend the applicability of this technique and increase its effectiveness at improving the ceramics’ mechanical performance. The next generation of ceramic engineers are being trained on these methods and approaches to enable the processing and implementation of tough structural ceramics. In addition to the two doctoral students, undergraduate and high school students are being recruited to participate in the project each summer.  

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This research identifies how grain boundary character (macroscopic parameters, thickness, and chemistry) in ceramics affects the propensity to form dislocations and, thus, build compressive residual stresses during LSP. LSP has been adapted to ceramic materials such as silicon carbide and alumina to induce compressive residual stresses that improve their crack resistance. Yet, the fundamental mechanisms and the broad applicability of the technique remain poorly understood. The scientific hypothesis is that LSP will be applicable to materials with higher order complexions – equilibrium grain boundary states with high disorder – to generate shock wave propagations that initiate dislocation formation necessary for building compressive residual stresses near grain boundaries. To test this hypothesis, the effect of LSP is being investigated in various grain boundaries of different character and composition in alpha-phase alumina with complexion engineering. The specific aims are to (1) correlate the extent of compressive residual stress induced by LSP with grain boundary character distributions and grain size and (2) identify individual grain boundary structures associated high dislocation density. Engineering students are learning valuable skills in ceramic processing and electron microscopy characterization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this work was to establish the limitations and controls for laser shock peening of ceramics, which is a potential process to improve the lifetime of structural parts used in aerospace and automotive industries. Laser shock peening is a common post-processing method to improve the crack resistance of metals. Recently, it was demonstrated in aluminum oxide and silicon carbide, two common structural ceramics. However, it was unclear whether the technique was widely applicable or what controls could be used to optimize its use in ceramic materials, which have different mechanical properties than metals. This work found (1) limitations of the technique’s feasibility in high purity aluminum oxide, (2) the significance of impurity phases and processing on the success of the technique, and (3) an optimized setup that allows for fewer materials and better mechanical performance.

Specifically, aluminum oxide, used in aerospace and automotive industries, was prepared with varying processing methods and impurity elements. High purity aluminum oxide showed no improved crack resistance from laser shock peening under a range of processing parameters. The introduction of impurities improved the material’s response. This finding implies that impurities are critical in the laser shock peening process. Laser shock peening was also performed and optimized for silicon nitride, a material used in aerospace industries. The mechanical response to laser shock peening was found to depend on the material’s internal structure (known as the microstructure). This finding suggests that the processing route of the material could be optimized to improve the effects of laser shock peening and, thus, the resistance to fracture. Additionally, the laser shock peening process was improved by performing at high temperatures and removing extraneous materials, giving more flexibility to the process. Traditionally, laser shock peening is performed at room temperature in metals. However, higher temperatures are desirable in ceramics to introduce atomic defects that help prevent fracture. Additionally, laser shock peening typically requires application of a sacrificial coating, which can be difficult to apply to complex part shapes and unstable at high temperatures. However, we demonstrated that the coating was not necessary for laser shock peening when completed at high temperatures in silicon nitride.

Overall, this work shows that the laser shock peening process is a viable industrial process for improving the crack resistance of ceramics but can be limited in high purity materials. Furthermore, we demonstrated that the process can be optimized by modifications of the material microstructure and use of high temperatures. This has important implications for its application to improve the lifetime of parts used in aerospace and automotive industries.

This project supported one published journal article and the thesis work for one graduate student and senior design project for an undergraduate student. The students were trained in material processing and advanced characterization methods. A graduate student was given support to attend a training workshop on fractography, the study of using imaging to analyze the point of failure, to evaluate the methods used in this project and then shared that information with a group of undergraduate students. The students learned professional communication skills, including technical writing and public speaking.  


Last Modified: 06/14/2023
Modified by: Amanda R Krause
